Macbride) Bacigalupi |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms=Castilleja douglasii var. contentiosa |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Feb–Aug(–Sep). |habitat=Coastal scrub, stabilized dunes, canyons. |elevation=0–500 m. |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Leafl. W. Bot. |publication year=1966 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1015.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja affinis |variety=Castilleja affinis var. contentiosa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja affinis]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja affinis var. neglecta |accepted_authority=(Zeile) J. M. Egger |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=90: 66. 2008 |year=2008 }} |common_names=Tiburon paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Castilleja neglecta |authority=Zeile |rank=species |publication_title=in W. L. Jepson, Man. Fl. Pl. Calif., |publication_place=936. 1925 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. affinis subsp. neglecta |authority=(Zeile) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja affinis;Castilleja affinis var. neglecta |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja affinis]]
variety[[Castilleja affinis var. neglecta]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 582, 583 |treatment_page=page 584 }}Stems: hairs dense, sometimes sparse, unbranched, rarely branched. Leaves not fleshy. Inflorescences 1.5–2.5 cm wide; bracts proximally pale yellow or yellow-green, distally yellow, rarely pink or pale red-orange, often becoming reddish tinted after anthesis, 3-lobed. Calyces green proximally, yellow in outer 1/2, after anthesis often whitish or reddish distally, 14–20 mm. Corollas 17–25 mm; beak subequal to or slightly exserted from calyx, 7–11 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Mar–Jul. |habitat=Serpentine meadows and slopes. |elevation=0–300 m. |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Variety neglecta is endemic to Marin, Napa, and Santa Clara counties. Its habitat is threatened by urbanization and recreational uses. Within its limited range, it is the only representative of Castilleja affinis on serpentine substrates and is recognized by its relatively narrow, yellow inflorescences.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja affinis var. neglecta |authority=(Zeile) J. M. Egger |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=C. affinis subsp. neglecta |basionyms=Castilleja neglecta |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Mar–Jul. |habitat=Serpentine meadows and slopes. |elevation=0–300 m. |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=2008 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1016.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja affinis |variety=Castilleja affinis var. neglecta }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja affinis]]

revision.comment: Bot: Adding category [[:Category:Revised Since Print|Revised Since Print]]
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja ambigua |accepted_authority=Hooker & Arnott |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bot. Beechey Voy., |place=154. 1833 |year=1833 }} |common_names=Johnny-nip;paintbrush owl’s-clover |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja ambigua |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja ambigua]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 570, 618 |treatment_page=page 584 }}Herbs, annual, sometimes biennial, 0.6–3.5 dm; with fibrous roots. Stems few to many, sometimes solitary (var. meadii), ascending or erect, often decumbent proximally, unbranched or branched above base, hairs sparse to moderately dense, spreading, long, soft, eglandular, mixed with short stipitate-glandular hairs. Leaves green or brownish in upland forms, linear-lanceolate to widely lanceolate, linear, elliptic, obovate, or oblong, rarely ovate or cup-shaped, (0.6–)0.8–5 cm, fleshy or not, margins plane, flat, 3–5(–7)-lobed, apex rounded to obtuse or acuminate, abaxial surface often stipitate-glandular, adaxial sometimes shiny, glabrous; lobes ascending to erect, linear to lanceolate, apex acute or obtuse. Inflorescences 1.5–9(–13) × 1–4 cm; bracts proximally green, rarely brownish purple, distally white, cream, pink, or purple on apices, lanceolate, oblong, or ovate, (0–)3–5(–7)-lobed; lobes ascending or divaricate-ascending, oblong to linear, short to long, arising below or above mid length, central lobe apex usually rounded to truncate, others acute to obtuse. Calyces green to pale yellowish green or tipped with white or purple, 8–23 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 5–9 mm, 33–50(–67)% of calyx length, lateral 2–5.5 mm, 20–40% of calyx length; lobes linear or narrowly lanceolate to oblong or ± triangular, apex acuminate or narrowly acute to obtuse or rounded. Corollas straight, 14–24 mm; tube 11–21 mm, expanded distally; abaxial lip and beak usually exserted, beak straight or slightly curved, adaxially white, yellow, or pink, sometimes green or purplish, (1–)4–7 mm, sparsely to densely short-hairy; abaxial lip pale to bright yellow, sometimes becoming pink, orange, or red after anthesis, with red-brown or purple spots at base of each tooth and sometimes at base of each pouch, conspicuous, pouches 3, ± prominent, divergent, saccate, 2–7 × 3–7 mm, (33–)60–75(–90)% as long as beak; teeth erect, sometimes spreading, white, pink, purple, or green, often with whitish bases, 1–3 mm. Filaments glabrous. 2n = 24.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=B.C.;Calif.;Oreg.;Wash. |discussion=

Varieties 4 (4 in the flora).

Castilleja ambigua is a complex species, treated here with four varieties, though many localized variations exist among populations, and these are still incompletely understood.

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Bract lobes linear; stems erect; moist inland meadows and vernal pools on volcanic substrates; c Napa County, California. |[[Castilleja ambigua var. meadii|Castilleja ambigua var. meadii]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Bract lobes linear to oblong; stems ± decumbent, at least proximally; coastal salt marshes, margins of brackish estuaries, coastal sandy bluffs, mesic to ± xeric inland grasslands; British Columbia to California. |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Bracts pink to purple distally; stems unbranched or few-branched from mid stem; salt marshes; Humboldt Bay region, nw California. |[[Castilleja ambigua var. humboldtiensis|Castilleja ambigua var. humboldtiensis]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Bracts white distally, rarely pink or cream; stems often branched from base; salt marshes, sandy coastal bluffs, inland grasslands; British Columbia to California. |[[#key-0-3| > 3]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Corolla beaks usually white or yellow, abaxial lips yellow; salt marshes, sandy coastal bluffs, inland grasslands; s British Columbia to c California. |[[Castilleja ambigua var. ambigua|Castilleja ambigua var. ambigua]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Corolla beaks usually pink to purplish, abaxial lips yellow, becoming white and then red or soft pink-purple; grassy coastal bluffs and adjacent sand dunes; vicinity of Monterey Bay, California. |[[Castilleja ambigua var. insalutata|Castilleja ambigua var. insalutata]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja ambigua |authority=Hooker & Arnott |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |distribution=B.C.;Calif.;Oreg.;Wash. |reference=None |publication title=Bot. Beechey Voy., |publication year=1833 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1017.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja ambigua }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Castilleja]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja ambigua var. ambigua |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Orthocarpus castillejoides |authority=Bentham |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja ambigua;Castilleja ambigua var. ambigua |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja ambigua]]
variety[[Castilleja ambigua var. ambigua]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 602 |treatment_page=page 585 }}Stems ± short-decumbent proximally, becoming ascending to erect, often branched. Leaves widely lanceolate, sometimes linear or narrowly oblong, rarely ovate, not fleshy, apex rounded. Bracts proximally greenish, rarely dull brownish, distally white, rarely fading pinkish, on lobe apices; lobes ascending, linear to oblong, 12–15 mm, usually arising near or above mid length. Calyces with all 4 clefts subequal; lateral clefts 2–3 mm, 20% of calyx length. Corollas 14–21 mm; beak pale to bright yellow or white, rarely pink, 4–6 mm; abaxial lip pale to bright yellow; teeth white, rarely pink or reddish purple.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Apr–Aug(–Oct). |habitat=Sandy coastal bluffs, inland grasslands, upper margins of salt marshes. |elevation=0–500 m. |distribution=B.C.;Calif.;Oreg.;Wash. |discussion=

Variety ambigua is highly variable among populations. Much of the variation tends towards two ecotypes. One ecotype has thin leaves with narrow, often acute lobes and more or less spreading-ascending stems. Plants of this ecotype inhabit sandy coastal bluffs and short-grass, herbaceous meadows, often well inland, in Marin, Napa, and Sonoma counties in California. Plants of a second ecotype have fleshy leaves and bracts with more or less obtuse lobes and more upright stems. These are found in Salicornia-dominated coastal salt marshes and range from southern Vancouver Island to San Francisco Bay. Plants found around Tomales Bay, Marin County, may have pink beaks. Variety ambigua occasionally hybridizes with Castilleja exserta and reportedly with C. rubicundula.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja ambigua var. ambigua |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Orthocarpus castillejoides |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Apr–Aug(–Oct). |habitat=Sandy coastal bluffs, inland grasslands, upper margins of salt marshes. |elevation=0–500 m. |distribution=B.C.;Calif.;Oreg.;Wash. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1018.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja ambigua |variety=Castilleja ambigua var. ambigua }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja ambigua]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja ambigua var. humboldtiensis |accepted_authority=(D. D. Keck) J. M. Egger |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=90: 67. 2008 |year=2008 }} |common_names=Humboldt Bay owl’s-clover |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Orthocarpus castillejoides var. humboldtiensis |authority=D. D. Keck |rank=variety |publication_title=Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., ser. |publication_place=4, 16: 536. 1927 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Castilleja ambigua subsp. humboldtiensis |authority=(D. D. Keck) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja ambigua;Castilleja ambigua var. humboldtiensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja ambigua]]
variety[[Castilleja ambigua var. humboldtiensis]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 584 |treatment_page=page 585 }}Stems ± short-decumbent proximally, becoming erect to ascending, unbranched or few-branched from mid stem. Leaves narrowly oblong to linear, oblong, or lanceolate, cup-shaped, ± fleshy, apex rounded. Bracts proximally green or brownish purple, distally pink to purple on lobe apices; lobes ascending, oblong, 20–23 mm, usually arising above mid length. Calyces with all 4 clefts subequal; lateral clefts 3 mm, ca. 15% of calyx length. Corollas 21–24 mm; beak pink or purplish, 5–7 mm; abaxial lip yellow, becoming orange or red-purple after anthesis; teeth deep pinkish purple, often with whitish bases.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Upper margins of Salicornia salt marshes, saline flats. |elevation=0–10 m. |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Variety humboldtiensis has purplish flowers and bract apices and is limited to the upper edge of Salicornia-dominated salt marshes in Humboldt and Mendocino counties, where it replaces var. ambigua. Most populations are around Humboldt Bay. Reports of var. humboldtiensis from Tomales Bay in Marin County are based on plants of the salt marsh form of var. ambigua and have yellowish flowers. Variety humboldtiensis is threatened by coastal development.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja ambigua var. humboldtiensis |authority=(D. D. Keck) J. M. Egger |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Castilleja ambigua subsp. humboldtiensis |basionyms=Orthocarpus castillejoides var. humboldtiensis |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Upper margins of Salicornia salt marshes, saline flats. |elevation=0–10 m. |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=2008 |special status=Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1019.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja ambigua |variety=Castilleja ambigua var. humboldtiensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja ambigua]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja ambigua var. insalutata |accepted_authority=(Jepson) J. M. Egger |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=90: 67. 2008 |year=2008 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Orthocarpus castillejoides var. insalutatus |authority=Jepson |rank=variety |publication_title=Man. Fl. Pl. Calif., |publication_place=944. 1925 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Castilleja ambigua subsp. insalutata |authority=(Jepson) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja ambigua;Castilleja ambigua var. insalutata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja ambigua]]
variety[[Castilleja ambigua var. insalutata]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 586 |treatment_page=page 585 }}Stems ± short-decumbent proximally, becoming erect to ascending, much-branched from base. Leaves lanceolate to elliptic to ovate or obovate, distal ones cup-shaped, not fleshy, apex rounded to obtuse. Bracts proximally green or reddish brownish, distally whitish, rarely pinkish or cream, on lobe apices; lobes ascending, oblong, 12–14 mm, arising above mid length. Calyces with all 4 clefts subequal; lateral clefts 5–5.5 mm, 40% of calyx length. Corollas 15–22 mm; beak pink to purple, 4–6 mm; abaxial lip yellow, becoming pink to red after anthesis; teeth deep to bright pinkish purple, often with whitish bases.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Grassy coastal bluffs, adjacent dunes. |elevation=0–100 m. |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Variety insalutata is now endemic to coastal habitats in northern Monterey County. This variety is also threatened by development, and past populations in Alameda County appear to be extirpated. Reports of var. insalutata from San Luis Obispo County are referable to other species.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja ambigua var. insalutata |authority=(Jepson) J. M. Egger |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Castilleja ambigua subsp. insalutata |basionyms=Orthocarpus castillejoides var. insalutatus |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Grassy coastal bluffs, adjacent dunes. |elevation=0–100 m. |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=2008 |special status=Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1020.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja ambigua |variety=Castilleja ambigua var. insalutata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja ambigua]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja ambigua var. meadii |accepted_authority=J. M. Egger & Ruygt |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytoneuron |place=2012-68: 2, figs. 1, 3–7, 9[left]. 2012 |year=2012 }} |common_names=Mead’s owl’s-clover |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja ambigua;Castilleja ambigua var. meadii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja ambigua]]
variety[[Castilleja ambigua var. meadii]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 584 |treatment_page=page 586 }}Stems erect, unbranched, sometimes with a few divaricate-ascending branches from proximal 1/2 of stem above base. Leaves linear or linear-lanceolate to lanceolate, 1 mm wide at base, not fleshy, apex acuminate. Bracts proximally pale greenish, distally white on lobe apices, often becoming entirely greenish with age; lobes divaricate-ascending, linear, 8–14 mm, usually arising below mid length. Calyces with all 4 clefts subequal or lateral clefts shallower; lateral clefts 2–3 mm, 25% of calyx length. Corollas 14–21 mm; beak pale, off-white, pale yellow, green with margins off-white, or yellow, sometimes orange, 1–4 mm; abaxial lip pale yellow; teeth white to green.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jun(–Jul). |habitat=Seasonally wet meadows with volcanic substrates in oak-pine woodlands or chaparral, shallow vernal pools, ephemeral stream margins. |elevation=400–500 m. |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Variety meadii is limited to vernally wet habitats, growing over rocks of the Sonoma Volcanic Formation in central Napa County near Atlas Peak. All known populations are under private ownership, and the variety is of conservation concern due to its very limited range. For the present, all populations except one are protected by conservation easements. Variety meadii often grows alongside, but does not hybridize with, Castilleja attenuata and C. densiflora. Ongoing study of annual species of Castilleja suggests this variety is genetically distinctive and may deserve full species status (S. J. Jacobs et al. 2018).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja ambigua var. meadii |authority=J. M. Egger & Ruygt |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jun(–Jul). |habitat=Seasonally wet meadows with volcanic substrates in oak-pine woodlands or chaparral, shallow vernal pools, ephemeral stream margins. |elevation=400–500 m. |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytoneuron |publication year=2012 |special status=Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1021.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja ambigua |variety=Castilleja ambigua var. meadii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja ambigua]]

revision.comment: Bot: Adding category [[:Category:Revised Since Print|Revised Since Print]]
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja angustifolia |accepted_authority=(Nuttall) G. Don |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. Hist. |place=4: 616. 1837/1838 |year=1838 }} |common_names=Northwestern or narrow-leaved paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Euchroma angustifolia |authority=Nuttall |rank=species |publication_title=J. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia |publication_place=7: 46. 1834 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja angustifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja angustifolia]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 575, 576, 587, 595 |treatment_page=page 586 }}Herbs, perennial, 0.9–3.8(–4) dm; from a woody caudex; with a taproot. Stems few to many, ascending to erect, branched, especially near base, sometimes unbranched, hairs sparse to dense, spreading to retrorse, long, sometimes short, soft to stiff, usually mixed with short-glandular ones, sometimes viscid. Leaves brown or purplish, sometimes green, linear to lanceolate or broadly lanceolate, 1.2–7(–7.5) cm, not fleshy, margins plane, sometimes ± wavy, involute or flat, (0–)3–5-lobed, rarely with secondary lobes, apex acuminate to rounded; lobes spreading, oblong or lanceolate to linear-lanceolate, apex acute to rounded. Inflorescences 2.5–20 × 1.5–5 cm; bracts proximally greenish or dull purplish, distally pink, magenta, pink-purple, reddish pink, pale yellow, pale yellow-orange, pale orange, or white, rarely reddish or orange-red, lanceolate to oblong, 3–5(–9)-lobed, sometimes with secondary lobes; lobes spreading or ascending, oblanceolate or linear, proximal lobes often much longer than distal, proximal lobes arising below or a little above mid length, apex acute to rounded. Calyces proximally green, yellow, brown, or purple, lobes colored as bract lobes, sometimes with a yellow band between proximal and distal parts, 13–25(–28) mm; abaxial clefts 3–8 mm, adaxial 5–9(–12) mm, clefts 30–50% of calyx length, deeper than laterals, lateral (1–)1.5–4(–5) mm, 10–25% of calyx length; lobes lanceolate to oblong, abaxials wider than adaxials, apex acute to rounded. Corollas straight, 18–27(–32) mm; tube 8–17 mm; beak usually long-exserted, adaxially green or pink, 8–15 mm; abaxial lip deep green, reduced, inconspicuous, 1–2.5 mm, 5–20% as long as beak; teeth incurved to ascending, deep green, 0.5–1.5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wyo. |discussion=

Varieties 3 (3 in the flora).

Much confusion exists concerning Castilleja angustifolia and the closely related C. chromosa. Sometimes C. chromosa is treated as a variety of C. angustifolia, using the name C. angustifolia var. dubia. The latter name is used here to represent a different assemblage of plants, not including C. chromosa. At other times, C. chromosa is synonymized completely under C. angustifolia. However, the two species are in most cases easily separable, and where they are sympatric there is little evidence of intergradation. Both C. angustifolia var. dubia and C. chromosa are accepted here. See additional comments under 3b. C. angustifolia var. dubia and 15. C. chromosa.

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Bracts distally usually pink to pink-purple; s Idaho, sw Montana, se Oregon, nw Wyoming. |[[Castilleja angustifolia var. angustifolia|Castilleja angustifolia var. angustifolia]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Bracts distally yellow, yellow-orange, pale orange, white, pink, reddish pink, or magenta; se Idaho, e Nevada, sw South Dakota, w Utah, ec Wyoming. |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Bracts distally usually yellow to pale orange or white; ec Wyoming, adjacent sw South Dakota. |[[Castilleja angustifolia var. dubia|Castilleja angustifolia var. dubia]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Bracts distally usually yellow, yellow-orange, white, pink, or reddish pink; se Idaho, e Nevada, w Utah. |[[Castilleja angustifolia var. flavescens|Castilleja angustifolia var. flavescens]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja angustifolia |authority=(Nuttall) G. Don |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Euchroma angustifolia |family=Orobanchaceae |distribution=Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Gen. Hist. |publication year=1838 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1022.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja angustifolia }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Castilleja]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja angustifolia var. angustifolia |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja angustifolia;Castilleja angustifolia var. angustifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja angustifolia]]
variety[[Castilleja angustifolia var. angustifolia]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 608 |treatment_page=page 587 }}Stems: hairs sparse to moderately dense, spreading to retrorse, long, soft to stiff, usually mixed with short-glandular ones. Bracts distally pink or pink-purple, sometimes pale orange, yellowish, or white, 3–5-lobed. Calyces 13–20 mm; abaxial clefts 3–6 mm, adaxial 5–8 mm. Corollas 18–25 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Apr–)May–Jul. |habitat=Dry sagebrush slopes and flats. |elevation=1300–2200 m. |distribution=Idaho;Mont.;Oreg.;Wyo. |discussion=

Variety angustifolia has pink to purple inflorescences over most of its range from southeastern Oregon and southern Idaho to southwestern Montana and northwestern Wyoming. At the eastern edge of its distribution, the colors vary more, possibly representing hybridization or contact with the more eastern var. dubia, which usually has yellow inflorescences. Plants of the western slope of the Big Horn Mountains, Wyoming, are morphologically intermediate between these two varieties. In the same area, var. angustifolia occasionally hybridizes with Castilleja flava var. flava.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja angustifolia var. angustifolia |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering (Apr–)May–Jul. |habitat=Dry sagebrush slopes and flats. |elevation=1300–2200 m. |distribution=Idaho;Mont.;Oreg.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1023.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja angustifolia |variety=Castilleja angustifolia var. angustifolia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja angustifolia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja angustifolia var. dubia |accepted_authority=A. Nelson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |place=29: 404. 1902 |year=1902 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Castilleja dubia |authority=(A. Nelson) A. Nelson |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja angustifolia;Castilleja angustifolia var. dubia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja angustifolia]]
variety[[Castilleja angustifolia var. dubia]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 586, 595, 657 |treatment_page=page 587 }}Stems: hairs fairly dense, spreading, short and long, soft to stiff, eglandular. Bracts distally yellow to pale orange or white, sometimes red, 3–9-lobed, sometimes with secondary lobes. Calyces 18–22 mm; abaxial clefts 5–7 mm, adaxial 7–8 mm. Corollas 18–27 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun. |habitat=Dry sagebrush slopes and flats in mountains, high plains. |elevation=1500–2400 m. |distribution=S.Dak.;Wyo. |discussion=

Variety dubia is often confused with Castilleja chromosa in herbaria, floras, and databases, but they are not synonymous. Where C. angustifolia and C. chromosa are sympatric in Wyoming, the specimens show little evidence of hybridization. Variety dubia, found primarily in southwestern South Dakota and east-central Wyoming, can be recognized by its usually narrower, yellow to pale orange inflorescences, as well as by its shorter corollas, while C. chromosa has wider, red inflorescences and longer corollas. Occasional hybrids between var. dubia and C. sessiliflora are known from northeastern Wyoming.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja angustifolia var. dubia |authority=A. Nelson |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Castilleja dubia |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Jun. |habitat=Dry sagebrush slopes and flats in mountains, high plains. |elevation=1500–2400 m. |distribution=S.Dak.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1902 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1024.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja angustifolia |variety=Castilleja angustifolia var. dubia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja angustifolia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja angustifolia var. flavescens |accepted_authority=(Pennell ex Edwin) N. H. Holmgren |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. Cronquist et al., Intermount. Fl. |place=4: 488. 1984 |year=1984 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Castilleja flavescens |authority=Pennell ex Edwin |rank=species |publication_title=Leafl. W. Bot. |publication_place=9: 45. 1959 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja angustifolia;Castilleja angustifolia var. flavescens |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja angustifolia]]
variety[[Castilleja angustifolia var. flavescens]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 587 }}Stems: hairs fairly dense, spreading, long, soft, with scattered, shorter, sometimes stipitate-glandular, ones. Bracts distally yellow, yellow-orange, white, pink, reddish pink, or magenta, usually variable within a population, 3–5-lobed. Calyces 21–28 mm; abaxial clefts 7–8 mm, adaxial 7–12 mm. Corollas 27–32 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Mar–)Apr–Jul. |habitat=Dry sagebrush slopes and flats, often rocky. |elevation=2100–3100 m. |distribution=Idaho;Nev.;Utah. |discussion=

Most plants of var. flavescens have yellow to pale orange inflorescences, but in some populations, such as near Wells, Nevada, the inflorescence can vary to pink, reddish pink, white, or magenta. Variety flavescens is associated with Artemisia arbuscula, its likely host plant, and is often found at higher elevations than Castilleja chromosa (N. H. Holmgren 1984). The variety is found in southeastern Idaho, eastern Nevada, and western Utah. Recent collections from extreme eastern Mono and Modoc counties suggest that var. flavescens may also occur in California, but the identity of these populations has yet to be fully verified.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja angustifolia var. flavescens |authority=(Pennell ex Edwin) N. H. Holmgren |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms=Castilleja flavescens |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering (Mar–)Apr–Jul. |habitat=Dry sagebrush slopes and flats, often rocky. |elevation=2100–3100 m. |distribution=Idaho;Nev.;Utah. |reference=None |publication title=in A. Cronquist et al., Intermount. Fl. |publication year=1984 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1025.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja angustifolia |variety=Castilleja angustifolia var. flavescens }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja angustifolia]]

revision.comment: Bot: Adding category [[:Category:Revised Since Print|Revised Since Print]]
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja applegatei |accepted_authority=Fernald |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Erythea |place=6: 49. 1898 |year=1898 |other_info_on_pub=(as Castilleia) }} |common_names=Applegate’s paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja applegatei |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja applegatei]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 573, 583, 588, 589, 591, 603, 610, 625, 664 |treatment_page=page 587 }}Herbs, perennial, (0.8–)1–5(–6) dm; from a branched, woody caudex; with a taproot. Stems few to many, erect, ascending, or decumbent, unbranched or branched, hairs sparse to dense, spreading, long, soft to ± stiff, eglandular, mixed with shorter stipitate-glandular ones. Leaves green to purplish or brown, linear to broadly lanceolate, sometimes ovate, 1–6 cm, not fleshy, margins wavy, involute, (0–)3(–5)-lobed, apex rounded or narrowly acute to acuminate; lobes spreading or ascending, lanceolate to broadly lanceolate, often short, apex acute to rounded. Inflorescences 2–12(–21 in fruit) × 1–5 cm; bracts proximally green to dull purplish brown, distally red, red-orange, or scarlet, sometimes orange, white, or yellow, rarely with a narrow yellowish band medially, lanceolate, broadly lanceolate, oblong, or lanceolate-ovate, 3–5(–7)-lobed; lobes spreading to ascending, linear, sometimes expanded near tip, long, arising from ca. mid length, central lobe apex obtuse to rounded, sometimes expanded, others acute, rounded, obtuse, or acuminate. Calyces proximally green or whitish, sometimes yellow, lobes colored as bract lobes, sometimes with a yellow band between proximal and distal portions, 13–25 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 4–14 mm, 33–50% of calyx length, deeper than laterals, lateral 2.5–8 mm, 12–50% of calyx length; lobes lanceolate-acuminate, narrowly oblong, or narrowly triangular, apex acuminate, acute, or obtuse. Corollas straight or curved in proximal 1/3, 16–35(–41) mm; tube 9–22 mm; beak usually long-exserted, adaxially green, yellow-green, or yellow, 6–20 mm; abaxial lip deep green to whitish or yellow, reduced, inconspicuous, protuberant, thickened, included or exserted, 1–3 mm, 5–20% as long as beak; teeth ascending or incurved, deep green to yellow, 0.5–1 mm. 2n = 24, 48.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wyo. |discussion=

Varieties 4 (4 in the flora).

Castilleja applegatei is a widespread and often common species, with complex patterns of variation and several common but inconstant color forms, especially in var. pinetorum. Castilleja disticha and C. martini, although sometimes included as subspecies within C. applegatei, are treated as species here. Both are more morphologically divergent and more easily distinguished from typical C. applegatei than are the four varieties accepted here. Variety pinetorum is the most widespread form and also occurs over a wider range of elevations than the other three varieties, which are primarily montane to subalpine and occasionally alpine.

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Corollas 25–41 mm, beaks 9–20 mm, tubes 15–22 mm; leaves usually 0–3-lobed. |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Corollas 34–41 mm; herbs 1–2.5(–3.5) dm; 2100–2800 m; Crater Lake to Newberry Crater, Cascade Range, Oregon. |[[Castilleja applegatei var. applegatei|Castilleja applegatei var. applegatei]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Corollas 25–35 mm; herbs 1.2–6 dm; 300–3600 m; California to Oregon and Idaho. |[[Castilleja applegatei var. pinetorum|Castilleja applegatei var. pinetorum]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Corollas 16–31 mm, beaks 6–14 mm, tubes 9–14 mm; leaves usually 3–5-lobed. |[[#key-0-3| > 3]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Corolla beaks 6–10 mm; abaxial and adaxial calyx clefts (4–)5–8(–10) mm. |[[Castilleja applegatei var. breweri|Castilleja applegatei var. breweri]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Corolla beaks 9–14 mm; abaxial and adaxial calyx clefts 7–14 mm. |[[Castilleja applegatei var. viscida|Castilleja applegatei var. viscida]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja applegatei |authority=Fernald |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |distribution=Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Erythea |publication year=1898 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1026.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja applegatei }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Castilleja]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja applegatei var. applegatei |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja applegatei;Castilleja applegatei var. applegatei |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja applegatei]]
variety[[Castilleja applegatei var. applegatei]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 588 }}Herbs 1–2.5(–3.5) dm. Stems usually branched. Leaves linear to lanceolate, sometimes ovate, 1.3–4.1 cm, 0–3(–5)-lobed, apex narrowly acute to acuminate. Inflorescences 3–8 × 2–5 cm; bracts distally usually red to red-orange or scarlet, 3(–5)-lobed, apex acute to acuminate. Calyces green, sometimes yellow, with red lobes, sometimes with a yellow band below lobes, 18–25 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 13 mm, 50% of calyx length, lateral 5–8 mm, 30% of calyx length; lobe apex acute to obtuse. Corollas 34–41 mm; tube 17–22 mm; beak 14–15 mm. 2n = 48.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Dry rocky volcanic slopes, open conifer forests, subalpine. |elevation=2100–2800 m. |distribution=Oreg. |discussion=

Variety applegatei is restricted to volcanic substrates in the higher elevations of the Cascade Range in south-central Oregon between Crater Lake and Newberry Crater.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja applegatei var. applegatei |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Dry rocky volcanic slopes, open conifer forests, subalpine. |elevation=2100–2800 m. |distribution=Oreg. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1027.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja applegatei |variety=Castilleja applegatei var. applegatei }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja applegatei]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja applegatei var. breweri |accepted_authority=(Fernald) N. H. Holmgren |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. Cronquist et al., Intermount. Fl. |place=4: 486. 1984 |year=1984 }} |common_names=Brewer’s paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Castilleja breweri |authority=Fernald |rank=species |publication_title=Erythea |publication_place=6: 49. 1898 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. applegatei subsp. pallida |authority=(Eastwood) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. applegatei var. pallida |authority=(Eastwood) N. H. Holmgren |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. breweri var. pallida |authority=Eastwood |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. glandulifera subsp. pallida |authority=(Eastwood) Pennell |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja applegatei;Castilleja applegatei var. breweri |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja applegatei]]
variety[[Castilleja applegatei var. breweri]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 589 |treatment_page=page 588 }}Herbs (0.8–)1–3(–4.8) dm. Stems branched from base. Leaves linear to broadly lanceolate, 1.2–4.8 cm, (0–)3(–5)-lobed, apex acute, rarely obtuse. Inflorescences 2–12 × 2–3.5 cm; bracts distally red, scarlet, or pale orange, rarely yellow, 3-lobed, apex acute to rounded, central lobe sometimes expanded. Calyces green to yellow, lobe apices red to yellow, 13–15 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts (4–)5–8(–10) mm, 33% of calyx length, lateral 3–5(–7) mm, 10–25% of calyx length; lobe apex acute, rarely obtuse. Corollas 16–22 mm; tube 11–13 mm; beak 6–10 mm. 2n = 48.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug(–Sep). |habitat=Dry rocky slopes, flats, open montane forests to alpine, granitic substrates. |elevation=1800–3600 m. |distribution=Calif.;Nev. |discussion=

Variety breweri is found in California in the high Sierra Nevada and in the mountains of adjacent Nevada. Hybrids with Castilleja chromosa and C. miniata var. miniata have both been found in Inyo County, California.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja applegatei var. breweri |authority=(Fernald) N. H. Holmgren |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=C. applegatei subsp. pallida;C. applegatei var. pallida;C. breweri var. pallida;C. glandulifera subsp. pallida |basionyms=Castilleja breweri |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug(–Sep). |habitat=Dry rocky slopes, flats, open montane forests to alpine, granitic substrates. |elevation=1800–3600 m. |distribution=Calif.;Nev. |reference=None |publication title=in A. Cronquist et al., Intermount. Fl. |publication year=1984 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1028.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja applegatei |variety=Castilleja applegatei var. breweri }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja applegatei]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja applegatei var. pinetorum |accepted_authority=(Fernald) N. H. Holmgren |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. Cronquist et al., Intermount. Fl. |place=4: 486. 1984 |year=1984 }} |common_names=Wavy-leaved paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Castilleja pinetorum |authority=Fernald |rank=species |publication_title=Erythea |publication_place=6: 50. 1898 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. applegatei var. fragilis |authority=(Zeile) N. H. Holmgren |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. applegatei subsp. pinetorum |authority=(Fernald) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. wherryana |authority=Pennell |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja applegatei;Castilleja applegatei var. pinetorum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja applegatei]]
variety[[Castilleja applegatei var. pinetorum]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 583, 588, 594, 603, 648 |treatment_page=page 589 }}Herbs 1.2–6 dm. Stems unbranched, sometimes branched. Leaves linear to broadly lanceolate, 1–6 cm, 0–3(–5)-lobed, apex narrowly acute to acuminate. Inflorescences 4–12(–21 in fruit) × 1–4 cm; bracts distally red, red-orange, or scarlet, sometimes orange, pale orange, or yellow, rarely with a narrow yellowish band medially, 3(–7)-lobed, central lobe apex obtuse, others obtuse to acute. Calyces proximally green, yellow, or whitish with green veins, lobe apices colored as bracts, sometimes with a yellow band between green and other color, 15–25 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 4–9 mm, 33–50% of calyx length, lateral 2.5–5 mm, 12–20% of calyx length; lobe apex acute to acuminate. Corollas 25–35 mm; tube 15–20 mm; beak 9–20 mm. 2n = 24, 48.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Apr–)May–Aug. |habitat=Open forests, rocky slopes, canyons, sagebrush hillsides. |elevation=300–3600 m. |distribution=Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg. |discussion=

Variety pinetorum is the most widespread and common representative of the Castilleja applegatei complex. It replaces var. breweri in the Sierra Nevada at low to moderate elevations. On the western flank of Steens Mountain, Harney County, Oregon, var. pinetorum occurs almost exclusively in a yellow-bracted form and has been confused with C. glandulifera. Variety pinetorum hybridizes with C. peckiana in Harney County, Oregon.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja applegatei var. pinetorum |authority=(Fernald) N. H. Holmgren |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=C. applegatei var. fragilis;C. applegatei subsp. pinetorum;C. wherryana |basionyms=Castilleja pinetorum |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering (Apr–)May–Aug. |habitat=Open forests, rocky slopes, canyons, sagebrush hillsides. |elevation=300–3600 m. |distribution=Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg. |reference=None |publication title=in A. Cronquist et al., Intermount. Fl. |publication year=1984 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1029.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja applegatei |variety=Castilleja applegatei var. pinetorum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja applegatei]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja applegatei var. viscida |accepted_authority=(Rydberg) Ownbey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in C. L. Hitchcock et al., Vasc. Pl. Pacif. N.W. |place=4: 299. 1959 |year=1959 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Castilleja viscida |authority=Rydberg |rank=species |publication_title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |publication_place=34: 38. 1907 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja applegatei;Castilleja applegatei var. viscida |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja applegatei]]
variety[[Castilleja applegatei var. viscida]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 588 |treatment_page=page 589 }}Herbs 1–3.1 dm. Stems unbranched, sometimes branched. Leaves broadly lanceolate, 1–4.5 cm, 3–5-lobed, apex acute. Inflorescences 2–12 × 1–4 cm; bracts distally red, red-orange, or orange, 3–5-lobed, apex acute. Calyces proximally green to yellowish, lobe apices colored as bracts, 14–24 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 7–14 mm, 50% of calyx length, lateral 7–8 mm, 33–50% of calyx length; lobe apex acuminate. Corollas 26–31 mm; tube 9–14 mm; beak 9–14 mm. 2n = 24.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering May–Aug. |habitat=Dry rocky slopes, alpine and open subalpine forests. |elevation=2100–3400 m. |distribution=Idaho;Utah;Wyo. |discussion=

Variety viscida occurs in the mountains of southeastern Idaho, Utah, and extreme southwestern Wyoming.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja applegatei var. viscida |authority=(Rydberg) Ownbey |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms=Castilleja viscida |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering May–Aug. |habitat=Dry rocky slopes, alpine and open subalpine forests. |elevation=2100–3400 m. |distribution=Idaho;Utah;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=in C. L. Hitchcock et al., Vasc. Pl. Pacif. N.W. |publication year=1959 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1030.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja applegatei |variety=Castilleja applegatei var. viscida }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja applegatei]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja aquariensis |accepted_authority=N. H. Holmgren |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |place=100: 87, fig. 3. 1973 |year=1973 }} |common_names=Aquarius Plateau paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja aquariensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja aquariensis]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 578 |treatment_page=page 589 }}Herbs, perennial, 1.1–3.9 dm; from a woody caudex; with numerous, thickened roots. Stems few to several, ascending to erect, unbranched, hairs moderately dense, often retrorse, short, ± stiff, stipitate-glandular distally only in inflorescence. Leaves appressed-ascending, green to purplish, linear to narrowly lanceolate, distal sometimes broadly lanceolate, (1–)2.5–4(–5.5) cm, not fleshy, margins plane, involute, 0(–5)-lobed, apex rounded to acuminate; lobes ascending, linear to narrowly lanceolate, apex acute. Inflorescences 2–7 × 1.5–2 cm; bracts proximally pale green to pale yellow-green, distally pale to bright yellow or cream, rarely pale orange, elliptic, narrowly ovate, elliptic-oblong, broadly lanceolate, or ovate, (0–)3(–5)-lobed; lobes ascending or spreading, narrowly lanceolate, short, arising near tip on distal bracts, central lobe apex rounded to truncate, lateral ones acute to rounded. Calyces proximally green to yellowish, distal 1/2 yellow, (16–)18–25 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts (8–)9.5–12.5 mm, 50% of calyx length, deeper than laterals, lateral 0.5–5(–6) mm, 5–20% of calyx length; lobes lanceolate to ovate, apex acute to obtuse. Corollas straight, 17–25 mm; tube 9–13 mm; beak exserted, adaxially green, 6–8(–12) mm, margins red or reddish brown, short-hairy; abaxial lip green, reduced, sometimes exserted, 1.5–2 mm, 10–15% as long as beak, glabrous; teeth erect, green, 0.5–1.5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Meadows with sagebrush, openings in spruce-fir forests. |elevation=2900–3400 m. |distribution=Utah. |discussion=

Castilleja aquariensis is endemic to the Aquarius Plateau in the mountains of south-central Utah. Its meadow habitats were severely degraded by livestock grazing, and at one time the species was a candidate for listing under the Endangered Species Act of the United States. It is still a species of management concern.

Castilleja aquariensis is in the Center for Plant Conservation’s National Collection of Endangered Plants.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja aquariensis |authority=N. H. Holmgren |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Meadows with sagebrush, openings in spruce-fir forests. |elevation=2900–3400 m. |distribution=Utah. |reference=None |publication title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1973 |special status=Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1031.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja aquariensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja arachnoidea |accepted_authority=Greenman |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bot. Gaz. |place=53: 510. 1912 |year=1912 }} |common_names=Cobwebby or cotton paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Castilleja arachnoidea subsp. shastensis |authority=Pennell |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. eastwoodiana |authority=Pennell |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. filifolia |authority=Eastwood |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. payneae |authority=Eastwood |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=C. pumicicola |authority=Pennell |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja arachnoidea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja arachnoidea]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 568, 571, 583, 655 |treatment_page=page 590 }}Herbs, perennial, 0.6–2(–3) dm; from branched, sometimes elongate, creeping basal stems; with a taproot. Stems solitary or few to many, decumbent-ascending, unbranched, sometimes branched, hairs dense, reflexed-spreading, matted, long, soft, unbranched, eglandular, white-woolly. Leaves green to purple or steel gray, lanceolate-linear or narrowly lanceolate, (1–)2–4(–6) cm, not fleshy, margins plane, involute, 3(–5)-lobed, apex acute; lobes spreading, linear to lanceolate, apex acute to rounded. Inflorescences erect to ascending, 3–12 × 1–2.5 cm; bracts proximally greenish to dull reddish brown, rarely dull red or dull orange, distally dull red, deep rusty red, or yellow to pale yellow, sometimes deep pink, dull rose, pale salmon, or dull light orange, rarely green, dull reddish, or dull orange throughout, aging browner and/or more orange, lanceolate or elliptic-lanceolate to obovate, (0–)3–5-lobed; lobes usually ascending, linear, lanceolate, oblanceolate, or spatulate, long, arising near or below mid length, central lobe apex rounded to truncate, others obtuse to rounded. Calyces colored as bracts, proximal part sometimes paler, (10–)12–19 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 4–8(–10) mm, 33–50% of calyx length, all 4 clefts subequal; lobes linear to lanceolate, apex acute. Corollas straight or ± curved, 12–20 mm; tube 9–15 mm; beak subequal to calyx or slightly exserted, adaxially green or yellow-green, (2–)3–5 mm, ± densely puberulent, hairs often crisped; abaxial lip yellow, greenish, pink, or red-violet, moderately conspicuous, exserted to barely included in calyx; pouches shallow, prominent, 2–4 mm, ca. 100% as long as beak; teeth erect, red, pink, or pale yellow, 1 mm. 2n = 24.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (May–)Jun–Aug(–Sep). |habitat=Pumice flats, sandy, gravelly, or rocky slopes, ridges and open summits. |elevation=1300–3300 m. |distribution=Calif.;Nev.;Oreg. |discussion=

Castilleja arachnoidea is a remarkably variable species in form and color, but inflorescence colors are often uniform within a population. It is sometimes confused with C. schizotricha, but the two differ in stature, lobing of the leaves and bracts, bract coloration, and inflation of the abaxial lip. They are easily separated by the simple hairs and pale yellow to brick red inflorescences of C. arachnoidea, compared to the pink-purple to deep purple inflorescences and branched hairs of C. schizotricha.

The names Castilleja eastwoodiana and C. filifolia represent yellow color forms of C. arachnoidea. A race on the pumice plains of Mt. Shasta in the Cascade Range in California is distinctive.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja arachnoidea |authority=Greenman |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Castilleja arachnoidea subsp. shastensis;C. eastwoodiana;C. filifolia;C. payneae;C. pumicicola |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering (May–)Jun–Aug(–Sep). |habitat=Pumice flats, sandy, gravelly, or rocky slopes, ridges and open summits. |elevation=1300–3300 m. |distribution=Calif.;Nev.;Oreg. |reference=None |publication title=Bot. Gaz. |publication year=1912 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1032.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja arachnoidea }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja attenuata |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Syst. Bot. |place=16: 656. 1991 |year=1991 }} |common_names=Valley tassels;narrow-leaved owl’s-clover |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Orthocarpus attenuatus |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=in War Department [U.S.], Pacif. Railr. Rep. |publication_place=4(5): 121. 1857 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja attenuata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja attenuata]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 570, 586, 591, 592, 602, 603, 606 |treatment_page=page 590 }}Herbs, annual, 1–4.5 dm; with fibrous roots. Stems solitary, erect to ascending, unbranched, sometimes branched from base, hairs spreading, short and medium, ± stiff, eglandular. Leaves green to purple-tinged, linear to linear-lanceolate, (1–)2–8 cm, not fleshy, margins plane, flat, 0(–5)-lobed, apex acuminate; lobes spreading to ascending, filiform to lanceolate, apex sometimes acuminate. Inflorescences (1.5–)2–10(–19, –30 in fruit) × 1–2 cm; bracts proximally green to pale brown, rarely dull reddish brown, distally white on apices, sometimes pale yellow or pale pink-purplish on apices, rarely greenish or dull reddish brown throughout, lanceolate or lanceolate-elliptic, 3(–5)-lobed; lobes ascending, linear to lanceolate, long, arising below mid length, apex acuminate, acute, or obtuse. Calyces colored as bracts, (8–)15–23 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts (4–)6–8 mm, abaxial ca. 50% of calyx length, adaxial ca. 75% of calyx length, lateral 3–3.5 mm, 33% of calyx length; lobes linear to narrowly triangular, apex acute to acuminate. Corollas straight, 10–25 mm; tube 9–20 mm, not expanded distally; beak exserted, straight, adaxially white, light yellow, or greenish, 3–5 mm, inconspicuously puberulent; abaxial lip white or yellow with deep brown to purple spots, often becoming pink, slightly inflated, exserted or not, pouches 3, 2 mm wide, 1–1.5 mm deep, 3–4 mm, 75–80% as long as beak; teeth erect, white, pale yellow, or pink, 0.5–1.2 mm. Filaments glabrous. 2n = 24.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Feb–)Mar–Jun. |habitat=Grasslands, pastures, moist margins of springs and streams, damp rocky slopes. |elevation=0–2100 m. |distribution=B.C.;Ariz.;Calif.;Oreg.;Wash.;Mexico (Baja California);South America (Chile). |discussion=

Castilleja attenuata is a common and widespread species, ranging from southwestern Canada to northern Baja California, with several disjunct populations in central Chile. It is sensitive to competition from weeds. Disjunct populations in the Rincon Mountains in Pima County, Arizona, often have pink bracts but are otherwise typical.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja attenuata |authority=(A. Gray) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Orthocarpus attenuatus |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering (Feb–)Mar–Jun. |habitat=Grasslands, pastures, moist margins of springs and streams, damp rocky slopes. |elevation=0–2100 m. |distribution=B.C.;Ariz.;Calif.;Oreg.;Wash.;Mexico (Baja California);South America (Chile). |reference=None |publication title=Syst. Bot. |publication year=1991 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1033.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja attenuata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja brevilobata |accepted_authority=Piper |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Biol. Soc. Wash. |place=33: 104. 1920 |year=1920 }} |common_names=Short-lobed paintbrush |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Castilleja hispida subsp. brevilobata |authority=(Piper) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja brevilobata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja brevilobata]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 573, 576, 577, 648 |treatment_page=page 591 }}Herbs, perennial, 1–5 dm; from a branched, woody caudex; with a taproot. Stems solitary or few, erect or ascending, unbranched, sometimes branched, hairs spreading, short, medium, and long, soft, short and medium ones short stipitate-glandular. Leaves green or ± yellow, lanceolate, elliptic, or oblong to narrowly ovate, 1–2(–2.5) cm, not fleshy, margins plane or wavy, involute, (0–)3–5(–7)-lobed, apex rounded to acute; lobes ascending to erect, linear to lanceolate, apex rounded to acute. Inflorescences 3–20 × 2–3.5 cm; bracts proximally greenish to dull brown, distally red, orange-red, or scarlet, sometimes orange or yellow, broadly lanceolate or oblong, (0–)3–5-lobed; lobes ascending, broadly to narrowly lanceolate, short, arising above mid length, apex acute, obtuse, or rounded. Calyces green or whitish with green veins, lobes colored as bract lobes or paler, 14–30 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 5.5–8.5 mm, 30–40% of calyx length, deeper than laterals, lateral 1.5–4 mm, 20–25% of calyx length; lobes oblong to narrowly triangular, apex obtuse to rounded. Corollas straight, 15–24(–26) mm; tube 12–16 mm; beak exserted, abaxial lip equal to calyx; beak adaxially green or ± yellow-green, 7–10 mm, puberulent, stipitate-glandular; abaxial lip deep green, reduced, rounded, 1–2 mm, 10–25% as long as beak; teeth incurved to erect, light green, 0.5–1 mm. 2n = 24.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Mar–Aug. |habitat=Dry savannas, rocky slopes and open conifer forests, on serpentine. |elevation=200–1700 m. |distribution=Calif.;Oreg. |discussion=

Castilleja brevilobata is endemic to dry serpentine openings in the Siskiyou Mountains of southwestern Oregon and adjacent California. Although sometimes treated as part of C. applegatei or C. hispida, its morphology does not suggest a close connection with either. This species occasionally hybridizes with C. pruinosa in Del Norte County, California.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja brevilobata |authority=Piper |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Castilleja hispida subsp. brevilobata |basionyms= |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Mar–Aug. |habitat=Dry savannas, rocky slopes and open conifer forests, on serpentine. |elevation=200–1700 m. |distribution=Calif.;Oreg. |reference=None |publication title=Proc. Biol. Soc. Wash. |publication year=1920 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1034.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja brevilobata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Castilleja brevistyla |accepted_authority=(Hoover) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Syst. Bot. |place=16: 656. 1991 |year=1991 }} |common_names=Short-styled owl’s-clover |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Orthocarpus brevistylus |authority=Hoover |rank=species |publication_title=Four Seasons |publication_place=2(4): 14. 1968 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orobanchaceae;Castilleja;Castilleja brevistyla |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orobanchaceae]]
genus[[Castilleja]]
species[[Castilleja brevistyla]]
|volume=Volume 17 |mention_page=page 570, 592 |treatment_page=page 591 }}Herbs, annual, (0.6–)1–4.3 dm; with fibrous roots. Stems solitary or few, erect, unbranched, sometimes branched, hairs spreading, short and long, soft and stiff, eglandular. Leaves green to purplish, linear to linear-lanceolate, (0.8–)2–6(–8.7) cm, not fleshy, margins plane, flat, 3–5-lobed, apex acuminate; lobes ascending, linear to narrowly lanceolate, long, apex acuminate to rounded. Inflorescences 5–25 (longer in fruit) × 1–2 cm; bracts proximally greenish to dull reddish brown, distally pink, lavender, magenta, purple-red, or white on apices, narrowly lanceolate, (3–)5-lobed; lobes ascending, linear to narrowly lanceolate with slightly widened apices, medium length to long, arising near or below mid length, apex acute. Calyces colored as bracts, sometimes proximally yellow, 15–20 mm; abaxial and adaxial clefts 7–9.5 mm, abaxial ca. 33% of calyx length, adaxial ca. 66% of calyx length, deeper than laterals, lateral 3–5.5 mm, 33% of calyx length; lobes ± linear, slender, all 4 similar, apex acute. Corollas straight, 15–30 mm; tube 14–23 mm, not expanded distally, majority of it exserted from calyx; beak straight, adaxially white or pink (drying purple), 4–6 mm, pubescent; abaxial lip ± inconspicuous, exserted, pouches 3, 2 mm wide, 1–1.5 mm deep, 3–5 mm, 50–70% as long as beak, white, yellow, or pink with large deep purple, red, or brown spot on each pouch at or extending below middle; teeth erect, white, yellow, or pink, 1–1.5 mm. Filaments glabrous. 2n = 48.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Mar–Jun. |habitat=Arid grasslands in hilly country, sagebrush or alkaline flats. |elevation=50–1200 m. |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Castilleja brevistyla is endemic to the foothills of the southern Sierra Nevada and the southern reaches of the Inner South Coast Ranges, in Kern and adjacent counties. It often grows with other annuals, including C. attenuata, C. densiflora, and C. exserta. The similar C. attenuata has three-lobed bracts and leaves, while C. brevistyla has mostly five-lobed parts, and also differs in corolla structure and spotting. Hybrids between C. brevistyla and C. exserta are known from Kern County.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Castilleja brevistyla |authority=(Hoover) T. I. Chuang & Heckard |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Orthocarpus brevistylus |family=Orobanchaceae |phenology=Flowering Mar–Jun. |habitat=Arid grasslands in hilly country, sagebrush or alkaline flats. |elevation=50–1200 m. |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Syst. Bot. |publication year=1991 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V17/V17_1035.xml |genus=Castilleja |species=Castilleja brevistyla }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Castilleja]]
